text: T helper differentiation proceeds through <extra_id_0> Stat1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent , <extra_id_0> Stat4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent and <extra_id_0> Stat4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - independent phases .

Much of our focus in understanding Th1 / Th2 development has been on the signals delivered by IL-12 and <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as final determinants of terminal T cell differentiation .

Because extinction of IL-12 signaling in early Th2 development could potentially be important in imprinting a more permanent Th2 phenotype on a population of T cells , we have also examined various parameters regulating the IL-12 signaling pathway .

Whereas <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> appears to repress functional IL-12 signaling through inhibition of <extra_id_0> IL-12R beta 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression , <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the mouse , and IFN-alpha in the human appear to induce <extra_id_0> IL-12R beta 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and promote IL-12 responsiveness .
We propose that Th1 development can be considered in two stages , capacitance and development .

Capacitance would simply involve expression of <extra_id_0> IL-12R beta 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> beta 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunits , regulated by TCR , <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IFNs .
The second stage , development , we propose is the true IL-12 induced developmental stage , involving expression of <extra_id_0> Stat4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inducible proteins .
In the human , this may also occur via IFN-alpha , which is able to activate <extra_id_0> Stat4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

It is perhaps possible that all of <extra_id_0> Stat4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> actions on Th1 development may be exert directly by <extra_id_0> Stat4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at the <extra_id_0> IFN-gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , however we suggest that , more likely , <extra_id_0> Stat4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may act to induce Th1 development through the induction of other non-cytokine genes , whose stable expression maintains the transcriptional state of a Th1 cell .
